resource.chars:
The extraction of uric acid from the Malpighian 
tubules of <u>Pontia <\u> substantiates and extends 
the observations of Plateau on the same organs 
in other insects.
Some of the earlier zoologists stated that the Malpighian 
tubules in the <u>Insecta<\u> represented the liver, and 
this statement has been recently revived by 
Lowne+ in his important work on <u>Calliphora <\u>. But 
the Malpighian tubules of the <u>Diptera <\u> (including 
<u>Calliphora<\u>), as well as those of the <u>Lepidoptera <\u>
and other <u>Insecta<\u>, readily yield uric acid when 
the proper tests are skilfully applied; and they 
do not contain the least trace of biliary acids,
glycogen, or even ferments.
The Malpighian tubules of the <u>Insecta <\u> are physiologi-
cally the kidneys of these animals; although, con-
cerning their place of development from the 
alimentary canal, they are the homologues of 
+Lowne, <u>The Anatomy, Physiology, Morphology and Development of 
of the Blow-fly <\u> (1890).
